children.name: to describe sb/sth in a particular way
describe sb/sth as
children.definition: describe somebody/something as/dɪˈskraɪb somebody/something æz/

children.name: mô tả ai đó/ cái gì là
examples: ▪Olsen described herself as a campaign manager for the organization.
Olsen mô tả mình là người quản lý chiến dịch cho tổ chức.
▪ Critics have described the book as ‘garbage’.
Các nhà phê bình đã miêu tả cuốn sách là 'rác rưởi'.
▪ Eliot was described by Lewis as arrogant, sly and insincere.
Eliot được Lewis mô tả là kiêu ngạo, xảo quyệt và không chân thành.
▪ How would you describe your relationship with your parents?
Bạn mô tả mối quan hệ với bố mẹ như thế nào?

children.name: say (that) sth/sb is
children.definition: say (that) something/somebody is/ˈseɪ ðət somebody/something ɪz/  to describe someone or something in a particular way, especially when this is your opinion and other people might disagree:

children.name: bảo rằng ai đó/ cái gì thì
examples: ▪ People say she’s too ambitious.
Mọi người bảo rằng cô ấy quá tham vọng.
▪ They say that Tokyo is one of the most expensive cities in the world.
Họ bảo rằng Tokyo là một trong những thành phố đắt đỏ nhất trên thế giới.
▪ It is an over-simplification to say that Britain is a democracy.
Đó là một sự đơn giản hóa để nói rằng Anh Quốc là một nền dân chủ.

children.name: call
children.definition: to use a particular word or phrase to describe sb or sth in order to give your opinion of them:

children.name: call sb sth
examples: Are you calling me a liar?

children.name: ‘She’s a fraud.’ ‘I wouldn’t call her that.’
examples: Already his followers were calling him a saint.

children.name: call sth sth
examples: What he did was wrong, but I wouldn’t call it a crime.
You may call it harmless fun, but I call it pornography.

children.name: call sb names(= use insulting names for sb)
examples: The other kids used to call me names, but I tried to ignore them.

children.name: label
children.definition: /ˈleɪbəl/  to describe someone, usually unfairly or incorrectly, as being a particular type or person, especially one that you disapprove of:
examples: dán, gắn mác
label somebody (as) lazy/stupid/uncooperative etc dán mác một ai là lười biếng/ngu ngốc/không hợp tác v.v
▪The unemployed are often labelled as lazy or unreliable.
Người thất nghiệp thường được dán mác là lười biếng hoặc không đáng tin cậy.
label somebody (as) a troublemaker/alcoholic/dissident etc dán, gắn mác ai đó là kẻ gây rối, con sâu rượu v.v
▪ When we’re ready to label them as suspects, we’ll release their descriptions.
Khi chúng tôi sẵn sàng để gắn mác họ là nghi can, chúng tôi sẽ công bố mô tả về họ.
▪ She lashed out at her critics who had labelled her a bimbo.
Cô lẩm bẩm những người chỉ trích người mà đã gắn mác cho cô là một cô gái bimbo.
labelverb[ T ]-ll-orUS USUALLY-l- dán nhãngán cho( ai )là…
to fasten a label to
_[ + adjective ]The parcel wasclearlylabelled 'Fragile'.
_If you spend any time in prison, you're labelled as a criminal for the rest of your life.

children.name: brand
children.definition: /brænd/  to describe someone or something as a bad type of person or thing, usually unfairly:gắn nhãn

children.name: brand somebody/something (as) unreliable/incompetent/foolish etc gắn nhãn một ai/cái gì không đáng tin cậy/ không đủ năng lực/ ngu xuẩn
examples: ▪Brown’s assistant has been branded in the papers as incompetent.
Trợ lý của Brown đã được gắn nhãn trong giấy tờ như là không đủ năng lực.

children.name: brand somebody/something (as) a racist/traitor/coward etc gắn nhãn ai/cái gì là phân biệt chủng tộc, phản bội, hèn nhát v.v
examples: ▪ Stalin’s opponents were branded as spies and traitors.
Các đối thủ của Stalin được gắn nhãn là tay trong và phản bội.

children.name: ▪ Government posters from the 1930s branded marijuana a ‘killer drug.’
examples: Các áp phích của chính phủ từ những năm 1930 đã gắn nhãn cho cần sa là 'loại thuốc sát thủ'.

children.name: hail sth/sb as
children.definition: hail something/somebody as/ˈheɪl something/somebody æz/  to describe someone or something as being very good, especially in newspapers, magazines, on television etc:
examples: tung hô ai đó, cái gì như ...
This new drug is being hailed as a major breakthrough in the treatment of cancer.
Many still hail Elvis Presley as the King of Rock ‘n’ Roll.

children.name: of sb or sth: to have a particular name
sb’s name is
children.definition: sth tên ai đó là cái gì đó
examples: Hi! My name’s Ted. I’m from Florida.

children.name: ‘Who’s that man over there?’ ‘His name is Lucio Mannonetti and he owns the company.’
be called
children.definition: to have a particular name - use this about a person, thing, or place: được gọi là

children.name: be called sth
examples: Our son is called Matthew.
Do you want to be called Miss or Ms?
The arrow that appears on the screen is called a cursor.
There’s someone called Russell on the phone for you.
What’s the new teacher called?
They are in favour of what is called ‘sustainable development’.
It was scarcely big enough to be called a school - it was more like a garage.

children.name: be called by sth
examples: I prefer to be called by my middle name.

children.name: be named
children.definition: /biː ˈneɪmd/  sb who is named Paul, Jane etc has the name Paul, Jane etc:
examples: được đặt tên là
▪ Their new baby is named Caroline.
▪ She went to the movies with some guy named Rudi.
a man/woman etc named sth(= someone with a particular name )
some guy named Bob Dylan
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually say sb or sth iscalledsomething rather thannamedsomething:
He had a friendcalledMick.

children.name: be known as
children.definition: if sb or sthis known as a particular name, that is the name that people call them, although it is not their real name: được biết đến như, được biết đến với cái tên ...

children.name: This area is known as Little Odessa because there are a lot of Russians living there
examples: And this is Terry,otherwiseknown as ‘Muscleman’.

children.name: be known to sb as sth
examples: He was known to his friends as Rambo.
be better known as sthđược biết đến nhiều với cái tên ...
William Shatner is better known as Captain Kirk.

children.name: be entitled
children.definition: /biː ɪnˈtaɪtld/  if a book, play, film, painting etc is entitled something, that is its name:

children.name: được đặt tựa là
examples: ▪ Her first published novel was entitled ‘Rivers of Passion’.
▪ Biko contributed a column to the student newspaper which was entitled ‘I Write What I Like’.
Her latest novel, entitled 'The Forgotten Sex', is out this week.

children.name: a documentary entitled ‘The Price of Perfection’
go by the name of
children.definition: /ˌgəʊ baɪ ðə ˈneɪm ɒv/  to be called something, use this especially when you are giving another better-known name for sth:được gọi là
examples: ▪ This kind of chilli powder sometimes goes by the name of cayenne pepper.

children.name: be termed
children.definition: /biː ˈtɜːʳmd/  to be called by a particular name - used especially in scientific or technical contexts: được gọi là
examples: This process, in which liquid metal is poured into moulds, is usually termed die-casting.

children.name: to give sb/sth a name that describes them
call
children.definition: gọi

children.name: call sth sth
examples: They call Chicago ‘The Windy City’.

children.name: call sb sth
examples: People call her ‘The Duck Lady of Lake Murray’ because she been feeding the ducks there daily for five years.

children.name: dub
children.definition: to give sb or sth a name, often a humorous name, that describes their character - used especially in newspapers: phong cho cái tên; gán cho cái tên, đặt cho cái tên
examples: dub sb/sth sth
The two men had such a reputation for drug abuse that they were dubbed ‘The Toxic Twins.’
The program to distribute Thanksgiving turkeys was dubbed ‘Operation Gobble.’

children.name: christen
children.definition: to invent a name for sb or sth, and use it whenever you talk about them, especially because you think it suits them or is funny: phong cho cái tên

children.name: christen sb/sth sth
examples: The band christened her ‘Mutti’ after the German word for mother.
The engine was affectionately christened ‘Puffing Billy’.

children.name: to publicly announce the name of sb
name
children.definition: /neɪm/  to publicly say who someone is, by telling people his or her name:
examples: cho biết tên, công bố tên
▪ She refused to name the father of her child.
name somebody as somebody
cho biết tên, công bố tên ai đó là ai đó
▪ Police have named the dead woman as Annabel Thomas.
nameverb[ T ]GIVE/SAY NAME gọi tên, đọc tên
to say what something or someone's name is
_In the first question you had to name three types of monkey.
_He couldn't name his attacker.

children.name: when the name of sb/sth is not suitable
so-called
children.definition: a word used to describe sb or sth that has been given a name that you think is wrong: cái gọi là, kẻ gọi là (ko xứng)
examples: I went to see the playwright’s so-called masterpiece and was very disappointed by it.
A lot has been written in recent years about the so-called ‘male menopause’.
It was one of his so-called friends who supplied him with the drugs that killed him.
where are your so-called friends?

children.name: misnomer
children.definition: formal a name that is not correct or does not seem suitable: sự nhầm tên
examples: The Palace of Justice - a terrible misnomer - was set on fire by the workers.

children.name: be sth of a misnomer
examples: The term ‘black-headed gull’ is something of a misnomer, since the bird’s head is actually brown.

children.name: nominal
children.definition: having the name of a job or position in society, but not actually doing that job or having the responsibilities that go with it: danh nghĩa
examples: It’s fairly clear that he is only the nominal head of the local party -- in fact he’s got no authority at all.
The daughter had all the brains and did all the accounts -- the son was just the nominal boss of the business.

children.name: in name only
children.definition: having a name or title, but not having the qualities or character that go with that name: trên danh nghĩa
examples: It’s a revolutionary party in name only -- in fact it’s quite conservative.
He will be my husband in name only - he knows I’m really in love with you.

children.name: self-styled
children.definition: use this about sb who gives himself or herself a particular title that you think they do not deserve and do not have a right to: tự xưng
examples: The self-styled Leader of the New Republic refused all attempts at negotiation by the former government.
These self-styled complementary therapists make a fortune out of preying on the gullibility of often very sick people.

children.name: to give a name to sb/sth
call
children.definition: especially UKto give sb or sth the name they will be known by in the future
examples: This is what psychologists call ‘body language’.

children.name: call sb Paul/Jane etc
examples: My mother wanted to call me Yuri.

children.name: call sb sth
examples: They’ve decided to call the baby Louise.

children.name: call sth sth
examples: What are you going to call the new puppy?
Guidebooks call Chicago ‘The Windy City’.

children.name: name
children.definition: /neɪm/  to officially give someone or something a name:
examples: đặt tên
▪ Have they named the baby yet?
name somebody Paul/Jane etc
▪ We named our daughter Sarah.
name sb/sth after sb(alsoname sb/sth for sbUS)
▪ Bill was named after his father.
▪ The new building is going to be named for Ronald Reagan.
nameverb[ T ]GIVE/SAY NAME đặt tên; gọi tên( ai ) là…
to give someone or something a name
_[ + two objects ]We named our dogs 'Shandy' and 'Belle'.
_A man named Dennis answered the door.

children.name: christen
children.definition: to give a baby its name at a Christian religious ceremony:
examples: đặt tên thánh
christen sb Paul/Jane etc
▪ They christened him Patrick John.
▪ She was christened Jessica, but everyone calls her Jess.

children.name: rename
children.definition: /riːˈneɪm/  to give something a new and different name:

children.name: đổi tên, thay tên
examples: ▪ You can rename, delete, or copy files very easily.

children.name: rename sth sth
examples: ▪ New Amsterdam was renamed New York in the 17th Century.

children.name: when you cannot remember or do not use the exact name
what’s its name
children.definition: / whatchamacallit/whatsitUK  informal spoken say this when you do not know the name of something or cannot remember it exactly: cái đó, cái gì đó
examples: Do you have a what’s its name -- you know, one of those things for taking off wallpaper?
I’ve broken the whatchamacallit on my purse.
You need one of those whatsits to turn the bolt.

children.name: what’s-his-name
children.definition: / what’s-her-name spoken informal say this when you cannot remember sb’s name: cái anh/cô gì ấy
examples: She was with what’s-his-name - you know, the one who wears orange jeans.
Send the report to what’s-her-name in Accounting.

children.name: thingy
children.definition: / thingamajig/ thingamabobspoken informala thing – used especially when you cannot remember the name of the thing, but often the other person knows what you are talking about : cái gì đó
examples: Can you pass me the thingy?
▪ You squeeze this little thingamajig, and it forces air into the pocket.
▪ The towels are on the thingy at the top of the stairs.

children.name: thing
children.definition: /θɪŋ/  spoken sth whose name you do not know exactly but that has particular features or is a type of the thing you are mentioning: thứ đồ
examples: ▪ He’s got one of those electronic things, you know, that you can record all your addresses in.

children.name: noun thing
examples: ▪ What’s that box thing on the table?
▪ She was wearing one of those Spanish type jacket things.

children.name: so-and-so
children.definition: an expression meaning a particular person, used especially when you are mentioning sb that another person often talks about, and their actual name is not important: nó
examples: Whenever you ask her about anything it’s always ‘so-and-so says this’, or ‘so-and-so says that’ -- she never gives her own honest opinion.
They’re always gossiping about so-and-so having an affair with so-and-so.

children.name: doodad
children.definition: US a small object whose name you have forgotten or do not know: cái thứ (mà)
examples: She kept pressing the buttons on the remote control doodad.
What’s this little doohickey for?

children.name: such and such
children.definition: informal an expression meaning a particular thing, used instead of giving examples of what you are talking about:
examples: Americans are very proud of their country -- they’re always saying that such and such is the biggest in the whole world.

children.name: such and such a person/place etc
examples: You can say to me, I want such and such a photographer, and I’ll try to get them for you.
If they tell you to arrive at such and such a time, just get there a couple of minutes early.
